sen.j: 「楽家録」によれば、その作法は、まず人長が進んで軾の前に行って3拍子を踏んで右足で軾を蹴って本方に立つ。
sen.e: According to Gakkaroku (fifty books on gagaku written by Suehiro ABE in 1690), the manner of the performance is as follows: a nincho (chief kagura dancer) goes in front of the shoku (straw mat), beats triple time, kicks the shoku with his right foot, and stands on the side of motokata (leaders, sitting on the left side of the niwabi at Mikagura, music performed in court shinto ceremonies).
sen.cmt: 「軾」は、「京都プロジェクト案件」の用語検索には「the front crossbar of a coach」とありましたが、広辞苑で「藁で作った円い敷物」とありました。後者の意味のほうが合うと思いましたので、「藁の敷物」を採用しています。
sen.e: According to the Gakkaroku (fifty books on gagaku written by Suehiro ABE in 1690), the Niwabi was performed as follows: a nincho (chief kagura dancer) would go to a point in front of the shoku (straw mat), dance in triple meter, kick the shoku with his right foot, and then stand to the side of the motokata (leaders who sat to the left of the garden fire during the performance of the Mikagura, a type of music performed in court Shinto ceremonies).
sen.cmt: I assume that the niwabi in "...left side of the niwabi…" is an actual garden fire rather than the music. Assuming I am correct in my assumption, I don't think there's any need to use the Japanese term in this case. Only using "niwabi" to refer to the piece of music would prevent confusion, I think.I also assume that this is no longer common practice so I have used "would go" rather than "goes", etc.Finally, "beat triple time" doesn't seem very clear to me so I have edited this based on the explanation of 拍子を踏む provided at the following site:http://www.geocities.jp/kiryuchuta/dance_nihongo.html
